update.description:
Implement the mechanism to support the use ```-fvisibility-inlines-hidden``` and ```-fvisibility=hidden``` in default compilation. This should ends up with a lower number of exported symbols which brings all [kind of benefits](http://gcc.gnu.org/wiki/Visibility) to the project, including faster loading times and less options of breaking the ABI.

Extensive testing will be needed to verify that all our plugin system is broken and dependencies on top of gazebo are not broken. Not only at compilation time, but at running time too (like plugins).

If you see a better way of sending this huge PR, let me know.
update.title: Use hidden symbol visibility by default

pullrequest.title: Use hidden symbol visibility by default

content.raw:
The `my_add_compile_flags` is a macro that calls another macro, and the macro is only used once. Is there a reason for this complexity?

An alternative to `my_add_compile_flags` could be:


```
#!c++

get_target_property(current_property gazebo_msgs COMPILE_FLAGS)
if(NOT current_property) # property non-existent or empty
  set_target_properties(gazebo_msgs PROPERTIES GENERATED TRUE COMPILE_FLAGS "-fvisibility=default")
else()
  set_target_properties(gazebo_msgs PROPERTIES COMPILE_FLAGS "${current_property} -fvisibility=default")
endif()
```
content.html:
The my_add_compile_flags is a macro that calls another macro, and the macro is only used once. Is there a reason for this complexity?

An alternative to my_add_compile_flags could be:

get_target_property(current_property gazebo_msgs COMPILE_FLAGS)
if(NOT current_property) # property non-existent or empty
  set_target_properties(gazebo_msgs PROPERTIES GENERATED TRUE COMPILE_FLAGS "-fvisibility=default")
else()
  set_target_properties(gazebo_msgs PROPERTIES COMPILE_FLAGS "${current_property} -fvisibility=default")
endif()

content.raw:
I was all the time assuming UNIX = Linux (don't ask me why) and really messing up with some dirty things to do exactly this, like 972c636. At this point, I'm ok with this decision, we will keep investigating the failures in osX and the clang support for visibility.

I have started a [new jenkins build](http://build.osrfoundation.org/job/gazebo-any-patched_protobuf-homebrew_bcn-amd64/26/).
content.html:
I was all the time assuming UNIX = Linux (don't ask me why) and really messing up with some dirty things to do exactly this, like 972c636. At this point, I'm ok with this decision, we will keep investigating the failures in osX and the clang support for visibility.

I have started a new jenkins build.

pull_request.title: Use hidden symbol visibility by default

pullrequest.title: Use hidden symbol visibility by default

content.raw:
That is a good point. The approach is to use hidden by default in the compiler and only enable the needed ones. Since it is quite a fine tunned feature, it is not trivial to know if we are overexposing some symbols that are really not needed. If a big problem appear (such a bug in gcc flags) in a minor or patch version our ABI checker will complain hard.

Others approaches exist: count the number of symbols and check if the increase is insane (imperfect), a test that generate a symbol collision if private classes are not exported, etc. I will need to think a bit more on this.
content.html:
That is a good point. The approach is to use hidden by default in the compiler and only enable the needed ones. Since it is quite a fine tunned feature, it is not trivial to know if we are overexposing some symbols that are really not needed. If a big problem appear (such a bug in gcc flags) in a minor or patch version our ABI checker will complain hard.

Others approaches exist: count the number of symbols and check if the increase is insane (imperfect), a test that generate a symbol collision if private classes are not exported, etc. I will need to think a bit more on this.

pullrequest.title: Use hidden symbol visibility by default

content.raw:
Added `-DGAZEBO_VISIBLE=1` to cppcheck in 46af355. Without this flag, I would get the following messages on Saucy:

```
#!c++

[gazebo/common/Event.hh:48]: (information) The code 'class GAZEBO_VISIBLE EventPrivate {' is not handled. You can use -I or --include to add handling of this code.
```
content.html:
Added -DGAZEBO_VISIBLE=1 to cppcheck in 46af355. Without this flag, I would get the following messages on Saucy:

[gazebo/common/Event.hh:48]: (information) The code 'class GAZEBO_VISIBLE EventPrivate {' is not handled. You can use -I or --include to add handling of this code.

pull_request.title: Use hidden symbol visibility by default

pullrequest.title: Use hidden symbol visibility by default

content.raw:
The UNIX variable is actually true for Mac OSX (see [cmake wiki](http://www.cmake.org/Wiki/CMake_Useful_Variables#System_.26_Compiler_Information)).
~~~
UNIX 
    is TRUE on all UNIX-like OS's, including Apple OS X and CygWin
~~~
If you want to disable for apple, you should say `if (UNIX AND NOT APPLE)`.
content.html:
The UNIX variable is actually true for Mac OSX (see cmake wiki).

UNIX 
    is TRUE on all UNIX-like OS's, including Apple OS X and CygWin

If you want to disable for apple, you should say if (UNIX AND NOT APPLE).

pull_request.title: Use hidden symbol visibility by default

pullrequest.title: Use hidden symbol visibility by default

content.raw:
I just made a branch called [hidden_symbols_diff](#!/osrf/gazebo/branches/compare/hidden_symbols_diff..default#diff) in which I revert a bunch of the changes from this branch to make it easier to view the diff.

I made three changes in this branch to remove the most repeated types of changes. For automated actions, I include the command that I used in the commit message, so it should be reproducible.

1. The `gazebo/util/system.hh` header file defines the `GAZEBO_VISIBLE` macro. Remove all instances of `#include "gazebo/util/system.hh"` (e88d5be).

2. Many gazebo classes have the GAZEBO_VISIBLE macro applied. Remove `GAZEBO_VISIBLE` from all class definitions (8cf361e).

3. Manually revert a few whitespace changes to reduce noise (3dfe619).

4. Merge in some code_check fixes (971bcf469624).

5. Merge in latest changes and resolve conflicts (33b65f445f3b).

There's still a lot happening in that diff, but it's boiled down to the list of API's that are explicitly marked as GAZEBO_VISIBLE.
content.html:
I just made a branch called hidden_symbols_diff in which I revert a bunch of the changes from this branch to make it easier to view the diff.

I made three changes in this branch to remove the most repeated types of changes. For automated actions, I include the command that I used in the commit message, so it should be reproducible.

  1. The gazebo/util/system.hh header file defines the GAZEBO_VISIBLE macro. Remove all instances of #include "gazebo/util/system.hh" (e88d5be).

  2. Many gazebo classes have the GAZEBO_VISIBLE macro applied. Remove GAZEBO_VISIBLE from all class definitions (8cf361e).

  3. Manually revert a few whitespace changes to reduce noise (3dfe619).

  4. Merge in some code_check fixes (971bcf469624).

  5. Merge in latest changes and resolve conflicts (33b65f445f3b).

There's still a lot happening in that diff, but it's boiled down to the list of API's that are explicitly marked as GAZEBO_VISIBLE.

content.raw: It is not. It is not a linker flag, but a compiler flag. The whole visibility thing for protobuf is needed, without it, [the compilation is broken](http://build.osrfoundation.org/job/gazebo-any-devel-quantal-amd64-gpu-nvidia/343/). I've remember that it was one of the first step I did while developing the branch.
content.html: It is not. It is not a linker flag, but a compiler flag. The whole visibility thing for protobuf is needed, without it, the compilation is broken. I've remember that it was one of the first step I did while developing the branch.
